intro: Bryantia butyrophora, commonly known as the buttercup plant, is a flowering plant belonging to the family Papaveraceae. It is characterized by its showy, yellow flowers with a distinctive cup-like structure, and it produces a milky sap that is toxic to some animals. The plant typically grows in moist, woodland habitats and is native to parts of North America. Bryantia butyrophora has narrow, grass-like leaves and is often found in shaded or partially shaded environments. Its botanical features make it an interesting subject for ecological and horticultural study.
